STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 17, 2019
Jennifer Vasilovski
Family and Community Services-Macomb
42140 Van Dyke Ave, Suite 110
Sterling Heights, MI 48314
RE: License #: CB500316267
Family and Community Services-Macomb
42140 Van Dyke Ave, Suite 110
Sterling Heights, MI 48314
Dear Ms. Vasilovski:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
04/08/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Christopher Barr, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-2282
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and
rules except for the following:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
Two out of three special evaluations reviewed did not document that the social
service workers were notified of what is required of the foster parent in the corrective
action plan.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to
the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical
care.
One out of eight applicable foster care case records reviewed did not contain
verification that the information noted in this rule was provided to the borrowed bed
foster parent before placement of the child in the home.
Repeat Citation from 06/01/2018 Interim Inspection
4

R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross.
Two out of eight foster home records reviewed contained late updated first aid
training. One record reviewed could not determine when the previous first training
was completed. The second record reviewed indicated first aid training being
completed on 12/14/2015, whereas CPR occurring on 08/20/2017 though did not
indicate first aid being completed though updated on 04/10/2019.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(2) An agency shall document foster home license changes in
the foster home record and shall communicate the changes
immediately to the department in the manner prescribed by the
department.
One out of eight applicable foster home records reviewed did not readily document
foster home license changes in the record and immediately communicate the
changes to the department. A relocation summary indicates the foster parent
relocating in 09/2018 and an application being signed by the foster parent on
10/01/2018. The relocation report and license change were completed on
11/20/2018. The relocation report did not include dates of home visits made.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.18 Page Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness
23
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative
foster parents within 180 days of the date of placement.
The agency has three enrolled relative homes that are beyond 180 days by two and
six months due to cooperation and special needs of adult household members. The
third was enrolled eight months beyond 180 days due to cooperation though has since
been sent to Lansing for denial.
Repeat Citation from 06/01/2018 Interim Inspection
5

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 Page
11-13
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
One out of eight foster care records reviewed was deficient in having quarterly
updated medical passports. The case record did not have a medical passport for
10/2018 and 03/2019.
DHHS Policy Health Documentation
FOM 801 Pages
2-25
All health requirements are to be documented and maintained
as follows:
•Age-specific Well Child Exam form. (page 2)
•DHHS-1664 Youth Health Record, Yearly Dental. (page 4)
•DHHS-221, Medical Passport. (page 11)
•DHHS-1643, Psychotropic Medication Informed Consent.
(page 25)
One out of eight applicable foster care case records reviewed did not contain
documentation of psychotropic medication informed consent on the DHHS-1643
form though was documented on the facilities own consent form. It is noted that the
facility informed consent form was submitted to the DHHS without being returned.
DHHS Policy Permanency Planning at 12 Months
FOM 722-07B
Page 1
The caseworker must complete a formal permanency goal
review annually from the acceptance date, or at any time a goal
change is being considered. The DHHS-643, Permanency Goal
Review, must be used to document the current permanency
goal, any barriers to the goal, and the action steps that will be
taken to meet the goal. A copy of the form must be filed in the
narrative section of the case file.
6

Four out of eight foster care case records reviewed did not contain an annual
DHHS-643 for 02/22/2018, 01/09/2019, 03/21/2019, whereas one dated 05/20/2018
was not yet uploaded.
DHHS Policy Unannounced Home Visits
FOM 722-6H –
Page 7
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the home
every quarter. The unannounced visit must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
Two out of eight foster care records reviewed were deficient one unannounced
home visit each. It is noted that monthly contacts were made.
Repeat Citation from 06/01/2018 Interim Inspection
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period. The agency completed a special evaluation conjointly with DHHS
due to corporal punishment being utilized in an isolated incident. The foster child
was consequently replaced from foster parent’s home and the foster parents license
was revoked. The agency’s actions were appropriate.
There were three incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period. One resulted in the foster parent’s license being revoked. The two
other investigations resulted in corrective action plans in which the foster parent was
to demonstrate knowledge of educational material regarding appropriate discipline.
The agency’s actions were appropriate.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The agency submitted a corrective action
plan for the 06/01/2018 interim inspection that successfully addressed the following:
determination of compliance in the reevaluation, foster parent signature on CAP, list
7

of children in a borrowed home, adoption evaluation completion within 90 days, birth
and foster parent signature on service plans. Repeat citations include the following:
Documenting unannounced foster home visits, foster child information being given to
foster parent before placement, and relative licensure within 180 days.
The 02/06/2019 analyst report was reviewed and follow up to safety issues and
concerns are as follows:
Safety and Concern Alert #1: No safety issues or concerns noted.
Safety and Concern Alert #2: No safety issues or concerns noted.
Safety and Concern Alert #3: No safety issues or concerns noted.
Safety and Concern Alert #4:
Urgent: The home does not have a carbon monoxide detector.
Resolution: The agency purchased a carbon monoxide detector on 01/25/2019
and delivered and installed it on 01/28/2019. Pictures of the receipt
and installed device are attached on the analyst safety and
concerns alert form.
Safety and Concern Alert #5: No safety issues or concerns noted.
Safety and Concern Alert #6: No safety issues or concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
04/11/2019
________________________________________
Christopher Barr Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 17, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
